Posts.Content: Aug 31, 2011 07:29PM watchfuleye wrote: My results showed both a numeric birads classification as well as an alph sub-classification.  I found the link below to be helpful in explaining the sub-classifications.  Hope this helps. http://www.breast-cancer.ca/screening/bi-rads.htm
Posts.Title: Bi rad scores AmyR SarahsMom

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2011 11:54PM watchfuleye wrote: Hi hope2011, I'm not sure I have any advice, but will share my experience FWIW. I just did the oral rinse BRAC testing last Thursday.  The NP at my surgeon's office told me that the oral rinse renders the same results as the blood test, and they use it now as it is less invasive, and less costly than a draw. You said the Lab is telling you they need a re-test.  What did your Doctor say?  Six weeks seems like a long time.  I was told my results would be back in two weeks. I'm sorry you are having this experience.  The waiting is always the worst -- especially to find out your results were inconclusive.  What is your new Doctor advising?
Posts.Title: BRCA testing hope2011 agada

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2011 06:17PM watchfuleye wrote: Hi everyone!  Thanks for the warm and kind thoughts.  :) I had my first visit with the surgeon yeasterday, and came away with a fistful of appointment schedules over the next two weeks for tests prior to surgery.  My surgery is scheduled for Sept 16th.  I also had the BRAC testing done yesterday, and they anticipate those results back in two weeks.  All in all, It's nice to have some dates and times to look forward to to help focus the steps on the path. :) Hope everyone is enjoying their weekend, as I am.  Hugs to all of you!

Posts.Content: watchfuleye wrote: Hi everyone, I'm moving down from the "waiting for results" forum. Don't know much yet, other than what appears in my siggy.  Initial visit with surg onc on Friday, and the scheduling of further tests of these dense breasts of mine to rule out (or not) any other spots/areas of concern.  I think I dread the hurry-up-and-wait part of this the most. I tried to tell God there are so many other ways to help me work on patience.  :) Oh well, wanted to introduce myself.  Love and light to those others who have just received this dx, and to those who are compassionate and open in sharing with those who have questions or just need someone to listen. Deep breath and keep smiling! "Catch a falling star and put it in your pocket, save it for a rainy day." Dx 8/16/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Room for one more on the couch? watchfuleye catbill

Posts.Content: watchfuleye wrote: I'm looking for some feedback from others to see if I am the odd man out here, or if there are others out there who share my sentiments.  Following my dx, DH and I made the decision to not share this with anyone else at this time except for my two sisters who would be most immediately affected from a family history standpoint.  I asked them to honor my request at this time to keep this between us until I have a final diagnosis following additional tests and surgery and we know what the course of treatment will involve. Well, it is now a week later and my youngest sister is wanting to know  "when I'm going to tell Mom" and not feeling comfortable in witholding information.  I am angry with myself for sharing with her now, as I really (1) don't want that pressure at this moment in time, and (2) my Mother is 77 and a BC survivor herself and I do not want to worry her needlessly until I have more information. But, I digress.  I guess I'm looking for someone who may have felt the same way as I am about not sharing this with everybody.  I am a pretty private person and I feel the same about my health issues. Am I being reasonable?  This really is bothering me tonight as I have no desire to share this outside of my DH and I. We do plan to share with our children and my other siblings at a future point, but I'm really regretting having shared with my sisters at all. I'm feeling backed in a corner and upset with myself for not keeping my mouth shut. "Catch a falling star and put it in your pocket, save it for a rainy day." Dx 8/16/2011, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 1/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How did you handle telling family when diagnosed? watchfuleye funsizejen

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 01:06PM - edited Aug 22, 2011 01:07PM by watchfuleye I can't tell you how much I appreciate all of you sharing your experiences with me.  I'm feeling more secure in my right to privacy through this ordeal, and the ability to control sharing this information when the timing feels right for me.  I know that once I share this with my Mother it will be out of  my control and she will telll e-v-e-r-y-o-n-e,  regardless of any request for privacy I make.   That's just the way my Mom rolls and the largest reason I dread telling her.    Unfortunately, my Mom doesn't know how to be supportive.  She is not a nurturer. She takes everything and makes it all about her.  As a result, what one might hope to get from their mother, she is not capable of giving.  I've seen it play out over and over throughout my life, and learned to not share as a result. Grrr!  I just re-read this and realized that the dysfunction in my family is once agin rearing it's ugly head. Perhaps the reason I've lived 1000's of miles away all these years. I so wish I had not shared with my sisters, but cannot unring that bell.  I can, however, decide what I choose to share going forward.  I did email my pressuring Sister and told her that I am sorry that I  placed her in a position to lie by omission, and I would release her from this burden just as soon as I could.  I asked her once again to just hang on for a few more weeks.  I hope she will honor my request. As one of you so aptly said, "a secret isn't a secret once you share it". Again, thanks to everyone for sharing.  It really means alot to me.
Posts.Title: How did you handle telling family when diagnosed? watchfuleye funsizejen

Posts.Content: Sep 1, 2011 03:53AM - edited Sep 1, 2011 04:09AM by watchfuleye Keeping your sister in my prayers that this turns out to be a mis-diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 01:50AM - edited Sep 3, 2011 08:28AM by watchfuleye I would agree with what LisaAlissa stated.  In my limited experience, any heat being generated is often a  sign that infection had started.  Even thought it's a holiday weekend, I'll bet you can raise someone on the phone to answer your question.  Good luck and be persistent....even if it means visiting your ER.
